page.title: 03THE HUNDRED HOUSE
page.content: Hundred House is a fine example of a Tudor black and white house. It stands in the centre of the village at the junction of the A53/A442 roads. It is a half-timbered house. For many centuries, the villagers had the right to elect their own{CORONER} on the steps of this house. Many centuries ago, it was also known as a{"Holly}Bush", because when there was a{Fair, Wake or Gala,}in the village, home brewed ale and wines were sold there. To show that this was legal, a holly bush was hung over the front door. Up until the 1950's, the{Court Leet was still held there every seven years This was an old court where the Lord of the Manor could try petty crimes of the villagers. The present occupiers of the lovely house are Mr. & Mrs. Jim Williams. Carol Bennett/D. Hewitt.
